I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak was declared a public health emergency 
of international concern by the World Health Organization on 30 January 2020, and thereafter 
declared a pandemic on 11 March 2020.1 The first cases were detected in December 2019 in 
Wuhan, Hubei Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC). Since the beginning of March 2020, 
the number of cases outside PRC has grown significantly. In Maldives, COVID-19 cases have 
spiked since 19 April 2020, with positive cases doubling every 4 days until 2 May 2020. Although 
the doubling rate has since improved to about 10 days during 3–12 May 2020, the cases continue 
to increase, with 1,841 confirmed cases, 608 recoveries, and seven deaths as of 30 May 2020.2 
To effectively deal with the pandemic, the government established a COVID-19 Task Force for 
overall  pandemic  response  planning and monitoring, and a National  Emergency  Operations 
Centre to oversee the activities of stakeholder agencies. A COVID-19 Response Trust Fund 
Committee was set up, with the finance minister as chair, for the oversight, and management of 
unemployment  benefits,  subsidies  on  electricity  and  water  bills  to  households,  and  the 
government’s economic response through subsidized working capital loans.  
 
2.  The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly added to the challenges affecting economic 
and social outcomes in the country. The government applied social distancing measures, closed 
schools and other public places, and subsequently declared a public health emergency for a 30-
day period across the country from 12 March 2020. The emergency has since been extended 
thrice with the current  directive  applicable  until  29 June  2020.  While  these restrictions  are 
necessary from health perspective, Maldives faces the risk of economic downturn because of the 
decline of the travel and tourism industry. The government projects a decline of 19 percentage 
points in 2020 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to –11.5% from its pre-pandemic estimate 
of  7.5%.  A drop  in  tourism  activities  will  adversely  affect  government  finances.  The  total 
government revenue in 2020 is estimated to drop by half of its pre-COVID-19 budget estimate to 
$990 million. Even after a 20% reduction in expenditure over 2020 budget estimates, the fiscal 
deficit–GDP ratio will rise to 13.7% in 2020 from 5.7% in 20193 and 6.2% (2020 budget estimate). 
 
3.  The government  introduced a countercyclical  expenditure  program of $351 million to 
mitigate the adverse health, social, and economic  impact of COVID-19, which consists of (i) 
COVID-19 pandemic response plan targeting the upgrading and provision of health facilities and 
supplies to support public health ($97 million); (ii) a COVID-19 social protection package for the 
vulnerable population such as the unemployed, poor, and vulnerable households, gender-based 
violence survivors, and expatriate migrant workers; (iii) subsidies to households on electricity and 
water bills ($124 million); and (iii) a COVID-19 economic response, providing subsidized working 
capital to the self-employed and businesses ($130 million). 
 
4.  ADB’s proposed COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support (CARES) Program, 
under the Countercyclical  Support Facility COVID-19 pandemic response option (CPRO), will 
support the Government of Maldives in implementation monitoring of its COVID-19 response plan 
(para. 3). It will allow the government to undertake public expenditures that are essential for 
supporting the vulnerable groups affected by COVID-19 and containing the spread of the disease. 
 
 
1  World Health Organization. 2020. Rolling updates on coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Geneva. 
https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/events-as-they-happen. 
2  Government of Maldives, Ministry of Health. Health Protection Agency COVID-19 Statistics Dashboard (accessed 
30 May 2020) 
3 Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA). Monthly Statistics. April 2020.

2 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the government  in effective monitoring and 
evaluation (M&E) and targeting of the government’s countercyclical expenditure program, build 
capacity in M&E, and identify areas for further public financial management (PFM) reform that 
can  be supported  by  ADB  under  a subsequent  program.  The  outcome  of the  TA  will be 
government's  health  response  and  socioeconomic  package  delivered  to  the poor,  women, 
migrant workers, elderly, and differently-abled, and other vulnerable groups, and businesses. For 
this, the TA will hire a variety of experts in social development, gender, economics, and finance, 
and support the government to achieve the outcome efficiently through the activities listed in the 
table below.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in Table 2. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office, administrative, and 
logistics  support,  workshop  venues,  translation,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The 
implementation arrangements for the TA are aligned with those of the CARES Program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer  the TA. The Regional  Cooperation  and Operations  Coordination 
Division of South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The following 
individual consultants are proposed to be hired (i) a Program Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist 
(International, 5 person-month), (ii) a Program Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (National, 5 
person-month),  (iii)  a  Gender  Specialist  (National,  8  person-months),  (iv)  an  Environment 
Specialist (National,  7 person-months), and  (v) an Environment  Specialist  (External Monitor) 
(National, 3 person-months). A firm will be engaged to strengthen Public Finance Management 
capacity of the government through  quality and cost-based  selection  method with technical-
financial ratio of 90:10. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.4
